instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..
definitions.LCDBKLT_BOOST: What is LCDBKLT_BOOST? LCDBKLT_BOOST is connected to the SWITCH(SW) pin of the LED driver and is switched to ground quickly after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit that boosts PPBUS_G3H to backlight voltage for the screen. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: 82-3437-A no backlight
threads.message:
Hello guys,

First thanks for all videos, it's fabulous to give a second chance to a lot of Apple products. Thanks Louis !

Here, I'm coming with a Macbook Air 2013 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A with no water damage (really, I never seen a computer as clean) !

I take some measures with my (very very bad) multimeter around <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> : <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> was about 0.06V so I shorted to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and is now 3.3V.


[IMG]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/filedata/fetch?filedataid=2109&type=thumb[/IMG]

All measures are shown. <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> looks a little bit low but I think it's my multimeter because I won't measure 8.46V as <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> but boost won't work, I agree.

I can't probe feedback track without removing <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> because I don't find any via... (They don't exist on my pcb version ?) Ho may I do ?

<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> isn't shorted.

PRAM reset is done.

What I'm wrong ?

Sorry for my English, I'm a little Belgian guy !

Regards,

Col

Bonus : the ugly short

[IMG]https://scontent.fbru1-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.15752-9/48366529_2331679290399558_4218892713539403776_n.jpg?_nc_cat=105&_nc_ht=scontent.fbru1-1.fna&oh=c4a86bada68aa28324086d492a0ae787&oe=5C9CDA66[/IMG]

threads.title: 82-3437-A no backlight
threads.message:
you soldered to a wrong test point. replace the chip and run a jumper from FB line to <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>. (check if you have continuity before you do this) 

also, your soldering bob is too big and that looks like a mess you are creating a short.
[IMG type="full" width="200px"]https://i.imgur.com/nx1vEkj.png[/IMG]
 


to [IMG type="full" width="200px"]https://i.imgur.com/GwdlOWH.png[/IMG]

threads.title: 82-3437-A no backlight
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> was about 0.06V so I shorted to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and is now 3.3V."
That is VERY-VERY BAD idea; you just injected 3V in a PCH pin!!!
For this (force) test, you MUST remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and inject 3V at <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR>.

A5 ball has a very small surface near chip; scratch it and check continuity to <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>.

Do you get image at least?
Did you test for voltage at pins 14, 18/19 of J8300?

threads.title: 82-3437-A no backlight
threads.message:
No Title

Thanks guys !

So I removed my jumper first...  Now, <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> is 8.52V and <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is 8.46V with screen.
I don't want to replace if it's not really needed :-)
I just scratch around FB and continuity probe to <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> : it's ok.

Pin 14 : 2.47V
Pin 18 : 3.31V
Pin 19 : 3.31V ofc

More pics :

[IMG]https://scontent.fbru2-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.15752-9/48397438_226708241558319_8175500261167464448_n.jpg?_nc_cat=108&_nc_ht=scontent.fbru2-1.fna&oh=8c57047ae161e124a8ce0d5630689422&oe=5CA7F6B8[/IMG]

:[IMG]https://scontent.fbru2-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.15752-9/48368443_501275687050222_5022737637312561152_n.jpg?_nc_cat=105&_nc_ht=scontent.fbru2-1.fna&oh=6c9bbdf6605ea2ccf906e4695736ddb3&oe=5C9318B1[/IMG]
[IMG type="full" width="200px"]https://scontent.fbru2-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.15752-9/48388203_594111131048407_4217543672901664768_n.jpg?_nc_cat=102&_nc_ht=scontent.fbru2-1.fna&oh=4b0479497026034a4e29de8549621534&oe=5C9CC23B[/IMG]

threads.title: 82-3437-A no backlight
threads.message: I think the problem is <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> but I don't find where it will be generate...

threads.title: 82-3437-A no backlight
threads.message:
"For this (force) test, you MUST remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and inject 3V at <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR>."
If you get backlight, check again <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>.
If is now high, remove 3V from <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR>, resolder <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and test.
Also check resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>; you could already f***d PCH output...

If no result, change <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.

threads.title: 82-3437-A no backlight
threads.message:
I just change <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, nothing more happend. All voltages still the same.

Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>EDP_BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> is about 168R (I don't know the precision of my multimeter).

Enabled is still a little bit low (not really 3.3V) and PWM is 0V but if i short to 3.3 (without <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR>), nothing more happen.

Thanks !

threads.title: 82-3437-A no backlight
threads.message:
Post resistance to ground on all connections to <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.
Use nearest components as test points.
